dt: {bc}to be different, opposed, or contradictory {bc}to fail to be in agreement or accord

quotes.t: Lily smiled faintly at the injunction to take her tea strong. It was the temptation she was always struggling to resist. Her craving for the keen stimulant was forever {qword}conflicting{/qword} with that other craving for sleep …

Mr. van Wolferen says the U.S. must do more: It has to openly explain to Japan that it wants a managed-trade deal in order to end the bickering between the two nations, a move that would {qword}conflict{/qword} with America's free-trade rhetoric.
The expectations about motherhood as full-time job that this situation created {qword}conflicted{/qword} with the philosophy of the women's movement of the l960's.

et: Middle English {it}conflicten{/it} "to engage in battle, fight," borrowed from Latin {it}conflīctus,{/it} past participle of {it}conflīgere{/it} "to strike together, bring into collision, do battle, contend" {ma}{mat|conflict:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to be different, opposed, or contradictory : to fail to be in agreement or accord

dt: {bc}competitive or opposing action of incompatibles {bc}antagonistic state or action (as of divergent ideas, interests, or persons)
{bc}mental struggle resulting from {d_link|incompatible|incompatible} or opposing needs, drives, wishes, or external or internal demands

dt.t: His conscience was in {wi}conflict{/wi} with his duty.

dt: {bc}the opposition of persons or forces that gives rise to the dramatic action in a drama or fiction

dt.t: The {it}conflict{/it} in the play is between the king and the archbishop.

pt: {sc}discord{/sc} {sc}strife{/sc} {sc}conflict{/sc} {sc}contention{/sc} {sc}dissension{/sc} {sc}variance{/sc} mean a state or condition marked by a lack of agreement or harmony. {sc}discord{/sc} implies an intrinsic or essential lack of harmony producing quarreling, factiousness, or antagonism.

pt.t: a political party long racked by {it}discord{/it}

pt: {sc}strife{/sc} emphasizes a struggle for superiority rather than the incongruity or incompatibility of the persons or things involved.

pt.t: during his brief reign the empire was never free of civil {it}strife{/it}

pt: {sc}conflict{/sc} usually stresses the action of forces in opposition but in static applications implies an irreconcilability as of duties or desires.
{sc}contention{/sc} applies to strife or competition that shows itself in quarreling, disputing, or controversy.

pt.t: several points of {it}contention{/it} about the new zoning law

pt: {sc}dissension{/sc} implies strife or discord and stresses a division into factions.

pt.t: religious {it}dissension{/it} threatened to split the colony

pt: {sc}variance{/sc} implies a clash between persons or things owing to a difference in nature, opinion, or interest.

pt.t: cultural {it}variances{/it} that work against a national identity

quotes.t: In great wars—the American Civil War, the First and Second World Wars—the largest casualties are suffered just before the {qword}conflicts{/qword} end.
At a moment when the country was still in the throes of the {qword}conflict{/qword} over Vietnam, it was refreshing to see the best of America.
… for work-family {qword}conflicts{/qword} to disappear, two rock-ribbed institutions must change: the whole concept of children's care, and the way the workplace works.

The basic {qword}conflict{/qword} in the novel is, of course, between the life on the river, where Huck finds innocence, brotherhood with man, and communion with nature, and life ashore, where, stage by stage, he discovers the corruption of society …

et: Middle English {it}conflicte, conflyte{/it} "battle, struggle, assault," borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French {it}conflykte, conflict,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}conflīctus{/it} "striking together, clash," from {it}conflīgere{/it} "to strike together, bring into collision, do battle, contend" (from {it}con-{/it} {et_link|con-|com-} + {it}flīgere{/it} "to strike, dash down") + {it}-tus,{/it} suffix of action nouns {ma}{mat|profligate:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: competitive or opposing action of incompatibles : antagonistic state or action (as of divergent ideas, interests, or persons)
mental struggle resulting from incompatible or opposing needs, drives, wishes, or external or internal demands

dt: {bc}ideas, feelings, etc., that disagree with one another

shortdef: ideas, feelings, etc., that disagree with one another

dt: {bc}to coordinate (something, such as flights, maneuvers, or the use of a location) between groups especially in areas where overlapping operations are occurring in order to reduce the risk of accidents or incidents

dt.t: A formal memorandum was signed in 2015 to {wi}deconflict{/wi} military aircraft flights and avoid airborne mishaps and altercations.

aq.auth: Gordon Lubold and Michael R. Gordon

dt.t: What was agreed by the two presidents is that our militaries would talk, so that we would {wi}deconflict{/wi} operations.
He began looking after the survivors, {wi}deconflicting{/wi} airspace for coalition aircraft coming in and out …

The [unidentified] military official said, {ldquo}Coalition patrol leaders and [the Syrian regime] checkpoint officer met face-to-face to {wi}deconflict{/wi} movement on the spot,{rdquo} adding that {ldquo}the interaction was professional.{rdquo}

shortdef: to coordinate (something, such as flights, maneuvers, or the use of a location) between groups especially in areas where overlapping operations are occurring in order to reduce the risk of accidents or incidents
